text: ਪਹਿਰਿ ਸਮਾਧਿ ਸਨਾਹੁ ਗਿਆਨਿ ਹੈ ਆਸਣਿ ਚੜਿਅਉ ॥

translation.text: Wearing the armor of Samaadhi, the Guru has mounted the saddled horse of spiritual wisdom.

transliteration.text: pahir samādh sanāh giān hai āsan chariau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਧ੍ਰੰਮ ਧਨਖੁ ਕਰ ਗਹਿਓ ਭਗਤ ਸੀਲਹ ਸਰਿ ਲੜਿਅਉ ॥

translation.text: Holding the bow of Dharma in His Hands, He has shot the arrows of devotion and humility.

transliteration.text: dhranm dhanakh kar gahiō bhagat sīlah sar lariau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਭੈ ਨਿਰਭਉ ਹਰਿ ਅਟਲੁ ਮਨਿ ਸਬਦਿ ਗੁਰ ਨੇਜਾ ਗਡਿਓ ॥

translation.text: He is fearless in the Fear of the Eternal Lord God; He has thrust the spear of the Word of the Guru's Shabad into the mind.

transliteration.text: bhai nirabhau har atal man sabad gur nējā gadiō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਕਾਮ ਕ੍ਰੋਧ ਲੋਭ ਮੋਹ ਅਪਤੁ ਪੰਚ ਦੂਤ ਬਿਖੰਡਿਓ ॥

translation.text: He has cut down the five demons of unfulfilled sexual desire, unresolved anger, unsatisfied greed, emotional attachment and self-conceit.

transliteration.text: kām krōdh lōbh mōh apat panch dūt bikhandiō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਭਲਉ ਭੂਹਾਲੁ ਤੇਜੋ ਤਨਾ ਨ੍ਰਿਪਤਿ ਨਾਥੁ ਨਾਨਕ ਬਰਿ ॥

translation.text: Guru Amar Daas, the son of Tayj Bhaan, of the noble Bhalla dynasty, blessed by Guru Nanak, is the Master of kings.

transliteration.text: bhalau bhūhāl tējō tanā nripat nāth nānak bar .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਗੁਰ ਅਮਰਦਾਸ ਸਚੁ ਸਲ੍ਯ ਭਣਿ ਤੈ ਦਲੁ ਜਿਤਉ ਇਵ ਜੁਧੁ ਕਰਿ ॥੧॥੨੧॥

translation.text: SALL speaks the truth; O Guru Amar Daas, you have conquered the army of evil, fighting the battle this way. ||1||21||

transliteration.text: gur amaradās sach saly bhan tai dal jitau iv judh kar .1.21.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood
